#  lmdb v0.8.0
Idiomatic and safe LMDB wrapper. 
  * [ #bindings ](https://crates.io/keywords/bindings)
  * [ #storage-engine ](https://crates.io/keywords/storage-engine)
  * [ #lmdb ](https://crates.io/keywords/lmdb)
  * [ #library ](https://crates.io/keywords/library)
  * [ #database ](https://crates.io/keywords/database)


  * [ Readme ](https://crates.io/crates/lmdb)
  * [ 11 Versions ](https://crates.io/crates/lmdb/versions)
  * [ Dependencies ](https://crates.io/crates/lmdb/dependencies)
  * [ Dependents ](https://crates.io/crates/lmdb/reverse_dependencies)


## Metadata
over 7 years ago 
[ Apache-2.0 ](https://choosealicense.com/licenses/apache-2.0)
22.8 KiB 
## Install
Run the following Cargo command in your project directory:
cargo add lmdb
Or add the following line to your Cargo.toml:
lmdb = "0.8.0"
## Documentation
[ docs.rs/lmdb ](https://docs.rs/lmdb)
## Repository
[ github.com/danburkert/lmdb-rs ](https://github.com/danburkert/lmdb-rs.git)

content.raw_markdown:
[](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/all.html "show sidebar")
# Crate lmdbCopy item path
[Settings](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/settings.html)
[Help](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/help.html)
Summary[Source](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/src/lmdb/lib.rs.html#1-123)
Expand description
Idiomatic and safe APIs for interacting with the [Lightning Memory-mapped Database (LMDB)](https://symas.com/lmdb).
## Structs[§](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/#structs)

[Database](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.Database.html "struct lmdb::Database")
    A handle to an individual database in an environment.

[DatabaseFlags](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.DatabaseFlags.html "struct lmdb::DatabaseFlags")
    Database options.

[Environment](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.Environment.html "struct lmdb::Environment")
    An LMDB environment.

[EnvironmentBuilder](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.EnvironmentBuilder.html "struct lmdb::EnvironmentBuilder")
    Options for opening or creating an environment.

[EnvironmentFlags](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.EnvironmentFlags.html "struct lmdb::EnvironmentFlags")
    Environment options.

[InactiveTransaction](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.InactiveTransaction.html "struct lmdb::InactiveTransaction")
    An inactive read-only transaction.

[Iter](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.Iter.html "struct lmdb::Iter")
    An iterator over the values in an LMDB database.

[IterDup](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.IterDup.html "struct lmdb::IterDup")
    An iterator over the keys and duplicate values in an LMDB database.

[RoCursor](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.RoCursor.html "struct lmdb::RoCursor")
    A read-only cursor for navigating the items within a database.

[RoTransaction](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.RoTransaction.html "struct lmdb::RoTransaction")
    An LMDB read-only transaction.

[RwCursor](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.RwCursor.html "struct lmdb::RwCursor")
    A read-write cursor for navigating items within a database.

[RwTransaction](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.RwTransaction.html "struct lmdb::RwTransaction")
    An LMDB read-write transaction.

[Stat](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.Stat.html "struct lmdb::Stat")
    Environment statistics.

[WriteFlags](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.WriteFlags.html "struct lmdb::WriteFlags")
    Write options.
## Enums[§](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/#enums)

[Error](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/enum.Error.html "enum lmdb::Error")
    An LMDB error kind.
## Traits[§](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/#traits)

[Cursor](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/trait.Cursor.html "trait lmdb::Cursor")
    An LMDB cursor.

[Transaction](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/trait.Transaction.html "trait lmdb::Transaction")
    An LMDB transaction.
## Type Aliases[§](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/#types)

[Result](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/type.Result.html "type lmdb::Result")
    An LMDB result.

[![Build Status](https://img.gs/czjpqfbdkz/full/https://travis-ci.org/danburkert/lmdb-rs.svg?branch=master)](https://travis-ci.org/danburkert/lmdb-rs) [![Windows Build Status](https://img.gs/czjpqfbdkz/full/https://ci.appveyor.com/api/projects/status/0bw21yfqsrsv3soh/branch/master?svg=true)](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/danburkert/lmdb-rs/branch/master) [![Documentation](https://img.gs/czjpqfbdkz/full/https://docs.rs/lmdb/badge.svg)](https://docs.rs/lmdb/) [![Crate](https://img.shields.io/crates/v/lmdb.svg)](https://crates.io/crates/lmdb)
# lmdb-rs
Idiomatic and safe APIs for interacting with the [Symas Lightning Memory-Mapped Database (LMDB)](http://symas.com/mdb/).
## Building from Source
```
```git``` clone`` --`recursive` git@github.com:danburkert/lmdb-rs.git`
``cd``` lmdb-rs`
``cargo``` build`
`
```

## Features
  * lmdb-sys.
  * Cursors.
  * Zero-copy put API.
  * Nested transactions.
  * Database statistics.


#### Dependencies
~89–435KB 
  * [bitflags](https://lib.rs/crates/bitflags "outdated") 1.0
  * [libc](https://lib.rs/crates/libc "0.2")
  * [lmdb-sys](https://lib.rs/crates/lmdb-sys "0.8.0")


  * dev  [byteorder](https://lib.rs/crates/byteorder "1.0")
  * dev  [rand](https://lib.rs/crates/rand "obsolete") 0.4
  * dev  [tempdir](https://lib.rs/crates/tempdir "deprecated") 0.3


  *[SLoC]: Lines of code, excluding comments

# lmdb-rs
Idiomatic and safe APIs for interacting with the Symas Lightning Memory-Mapped Database (LMDB)⟨9⟩.
## Building from Source
```
```git``` clone`` --`recursive` git@github.com:danburkert/lmdb-rs.git`
``cd``` lmdb-rs`
``cargo``` build`
`
```

## Features
  * lmdb-sys.
  * Cursors.
  * Zero-copy put API.
  * Nested transactions.
  * Database statistics.


#### Dependencies
~89–435KB 
  * bitflags⟨10⟩ 1.0
  * libc⟨11⟩
  * lmdb-sys⟨12⟩

advisory.title: Race Condition Enabling Link Following and Time-of-check Time-of-use (TOCTOU)
advisory.description:
The remove_dir_all crate is a Rust library that offers additional features over the Rust
standard library fs::remove_dir_all function.

It was possible to trick a privileged process doing a recursive delete in an
attacker controlled directory into deleting privileged files, on all operating systems.

For instance, consider deleting a tree called 'etc' in a parent directory
called 'p'. Between calling `remove_dir_all("a")` and remove_dir_all("a")
actually starting its work, the attacker can move 'p' to 'p-prime', and
replace 'p' with a symlink to '/'. Then the privileged process deletes 'p/etc'
which is actually /etc, and now your system is broken. There are some
mitigations for this exact scenario, such as CWD relative file lookup, but
they are not guaranteed - any code using absolute paths will not have that
protection in place.

The same attack could be performed at any point in the directory tree being
deleted: if 'a' contains a child directory called 'etc', attacking the
deletion by replacing 'a' with a link is possible.

The new code in this release mitigates the attack within the directory tree
being deleted by using file-handle relative operations: to open 'a/etc', the
path 'etc' relative to 'a' is opened, where 'a' is represented by a file
descriptor (Unix) or handle (Windows). With the exception of the entry points
into the directory deletion logic, this is robust against manipulation of the
directory hierarchy, and remove_dir_all will only delete files and directories
contained in the tree it is deleting.

The entry path however is a challenge - as described above, there are some
potential mitigations, but since using them must be done by the calling code,
it is hard to be confident about the security properties of the path based
interface.

The new extension trait `RemoveDir` provides an interface where it is much
harder to get it wrong.

`somedir.remove_dir_contents("name-of-child")`.

Callers can then make their own security evaluation about how to securely get
a directory handle. That is still not particularly obvious, and we're going to
follow up with a helper of some sort (probably in the `fs_at` crate). Once
that is available, the path based entry points will get deprecated.

In the interim, processes that might run with elevated privileges should
figure out how to securely identify the directory they are going to delete, to
avoid the initial race. Pragmatically, other processes should be fine with the
path based entry points : this is the same interface `std::fs::remove_dir_all`
offers, and an unprivileged process running in an attacker controlled
directory can't do anything that the attacker can't already do.

advisory.title: lmdb is unmaintained, use lmdb-rkv instead
advisory.description:
The lmdb crate hasn't had any updates since August 2018.

Mozilla's [lmdb-rkv](https://github.com/mozilla/lmdb-rs) fork of the crate has received additional maintenance work beyond that and is the best available replacement.

advisory.title: `tempdir` crate has been deprecated; use `tempfile` instead
advisory.description:
The [`tempdir`](https://crates.io/crates/tempdir) crate has been deprecated
and the functionality is merged into [`tempfile`](https://crates.io/crates/tempfile).

crate_analysis.note: Crate analysis performed with stable toolchain.

# Crate lmdbCopy item path
[Settings](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/settings.html)

Summary[Source](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/src/lmdb/lib.rs.html#1-123)
Expand description
Idiomatic and safe APIs for interacting with the [Lightning Memory-mapped Database (LMDB)](https://symas.com/lmdb).
## Structs[§](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/#structs)

[Database](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.Database.html "struct lmdb::Database")
    A handle to an individual database in an environment.

[DatabaseFlags](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.DatabaseFlags.html "struct lmdb::DatabaseFlags")
    Database options.

[Environment](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.Environment.html "struct lmdb::Environment")
    An LMDB environment.

[EnvironmentBuilder](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.EnvironmentBuilder.html "struct lmdb::EnvironmentBuilder")
    Options for opening or creating an environment.

[EnvironmentFlags](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.EnvironmentFlags.html "struct lmdb::EnvironmentFlags")
    Environment options.

[InactiveTransaction](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.InactiveTransaction.html "struct lmdb::InactiveTransaction")
    An inactive read-only transaction.

[Iter](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.Iter.html "struct lmdb::Iter")
    An iterator over the values in an LMDB database.

[IterDup](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.IterDup.html "struct lmdb::IterDup")
    An iterator over the keys and duplicate values in an LMDB database.

[RoCursor](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.RoCursor.html "struct lmdb::RoCursor")
    A read-only cursor for navigating the items within a database.

[RoTransaction](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.RoTransaction.html "struct lmdb::RoTransaction")
    An LMDB read-only transaction.

[RwCursor](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.RwCursor.html "struct lmdb::RwCursor")
    A read-write cursor for navigating items within a database.

[RwTransaction](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.RwTransaction.html "struct lmdb::RwTransaction")
    An LMDB read-write transaction.

[Stat](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.Stat.html "struct lmdb::Stat")
    Environment statistics.

[WriteFlags](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/struct.WriteFlags.html "struct lmdb::WriteFlags")
    Write options.
## Enums[§](https://docs.rs/lmdb/latest/lmdb/#enums)

enriched_crate.readme_summary: The `lmdb` crate provides idiomatic and safe Rust APIs for interacting with the Lightning Memory-mapped Database (LMDB), a high-performance key-value store. It offers robust abstractions for managing environments, databases, transactions (read-only and read-write), cursors, and iterators, along with configurable options for environments and writes. The crate ensures safety and ease of use while handling LMDB operations, including error management and statistics retrieval.
enriched_crate.factual_counterfactual:
### Pair 1: Environment Management  
✅ Factual: The `lmdb` crate provides an `EnvironmentBuilder` struct that allows users to configure and create LMDB environments with options such as maximum database size and number of databases.  
❌ Counterfactual: The `lmdb` crate does not allow configuration of LMDB environments; all environments must use default settings without customization.  

---

### Pair 2: Transaction Handling  
✅ Factual: The `lmdb` crate supports both read-only (`RoTransaction`) and read-write (`RwTransaction`) transactions, enabling flexible access patterns for database operations.  
❌ Counterfactual: The `lmdb` crate only supports read-write transactions, making it unsuitable for scenarios requiring read-only access.  

---

### Pair 3: Iteration Over Database Entries  
✅ Factual: The `lmdb` crate provides iterators such as `Iter` and `IterDup` for traversing database entries, including support for duplicate keys.  
❌ Counterfactual: The `lmdb` crate does not provide any iterator functionality, requiring manual traversal of database entries using raw pointers.
